Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Project: Combating ESKAPE pathogens through discovery of novel antimicrobial and antibiofilm molecules

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Fayetteville State University intends to look at soil microbes and identify the chemicals they produce to kill bacteria. The identification of these microbes and chemicals will have implications in understanding biological films. Fayetteville State University undergraduate students will have the opportunity to perform research.

The goal of the proposed study is to collect soil from various environmental areas such as oceanic, mountainous, and natural preserve regions, define the physiological cultural conditions and identify the chemistry of small molecules bacteria produce in efforts to understand how these organisms kill other bacteria, particularly ESKAPE pathogens, while not harming themselves. The specific objectives of the proposed research are 1) to identify and characterize the physical and chemical properties of antimicrobial producing soil microbes that inhibit safe-ESKAPE relative strains, and 2) determine the effect of soil microbes on biofilm formation, dispersal and gene expression of safe ESKAPE relative strains. The findings from the research outlined in this proposal will enhance our understanding of microbe-microbe interactions and further advance the knowledge of antibiotic discovery using a tried and true method of mining soil microbes coupled with a metagenomic and computational approach. The implementation of the proposed research will provide an opportunity for underrepresented groups to gain hands-on research experience, access state of the art equipment as well as cutting edge techniques through the collaboration with UNC Chapel Hill and develop a collaborative network of student researchers and faculty.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted through this project has significantly advanced our understanding of microbial interactions and their role in antibiotic discovery. The project identified bacteria that could produce novel antimicrobial compounds by isolating soil microbes from diverse environments.

Approximately 10–20% of the isolates demonstrated inhibitory activity against safe ESKAPE relatives, highlighting their promise as a source for combating antibiotic resistance. These findings shed light on the intricate dynamics of microbe-microbe interactions and offer valuable insights into developing new antibiotics, an area of critical global importance.

The research provides a deeper understanding of antimicrobial-producing microbes' chemical and genetic properties. It has also enhanced the scientific community's ability to mine soil bacteria for novel therapeutic agents. This project exemplifies the intellectual merit of using innovative approaches to address pressing challenges in microbiology and biotechnology.

The broader impacts of this research extend to education, diversity, and community engagement. As a Historically Black University, Fayetteville State University provided an inclusive platform for underrepresented students to engage in meaningful research experiences. Undergraduate participants gained hands-on training in advanced laboratory techniques, strengthened their critical thinking and problem-solving skills, and improved their oral and written communication skills. They were also introduced to a global network of researchers and collaborators. These experiences gave students the tools to pursue advanced degrees or competitive STEM careers, contributing to a more diverse and skilled workforce.

The project also fostered community outreach, with researchers engaging local middle and high schools to promote scientific literacy. By sharing accurate information on bacteria, antibiotics, and resistance, the team inspired younger students and underscored the societal importance of scientific research. Overall, the outcomes of this project not only advanced the frontiers of antibiotic discovery but also enriched the educational and professional development of the next generation of scientists while fostering a broader appreciation for the role of science in addressing global challenges.
